clinical_study.brief_title: Office-based Radial Expansion Balloon Dilation of the Esophagus and Trachea
clinical_study.official_title: Office-based Radial Expansion Balloon Dilation of the Esophagus and Trachea

brief_summary.textblock: Retrospective chart review of UCDMC patients who have undergone esophageal or tracheal balloon dilation to record data including age, gender, diagnosis pre-and post-procedure eating assessment tool, esophagoscopy findings, tracheobronchoscopy findings, and pre-and post-procedure videofluoroscopic findings.

detailed_description.textblock: Dilation of the esophagus is performed for strictures, webs, and rings at all levels of the esophagus. Dilation of the trachea is performed for subglottic and tracheal stenosis. Radial expansion balloons have been developed by Bost Scientific Corporation for the purpose of dilating the esophagus and trachea through flexible esophagoscopies. These sequential controlled radial-expansion balloons can be introduced via a guide wire through the working channel of a 5.1 mm transnasal esophagoscope. Traditionally, otolaryngologists have performed esophageal and tracheal dilation per oral under general anesthesia. This technique allows the procedure to be performed in the office, sparing the patient the risk of anesthetics. The purpose of this study is to review the UCDMC experience with esophageal and tracheal balloon dilation using the transnasal esophagoscope.

clinical_study.why_stopped: PI chose not to proceed with study.

study_pop.textblock: UCDMC Otolaryngology Voice and Swallowing Center patients

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients who have undergone esophageal or tracheal balloon dilation since 1/1/05
- patients who underwent an attempted dilation since 1/1/05
Exclusion Criteria:
- Younger than 18 years of age
- Those who do not meet the inclusion criteria
